ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I improved my speaking and grammar skills by taking this course.
I learned basic Chinese reading, writing, and speaking.
I learned how to read and write Chinese and corrected my grammar. Through this course, I improved my Chinese communication skills and look forward to learning the language.

I have built a solid foundation for pinyin pronunciation/inflection, character recognition, and listening comprehension in Chinese. I have also saw significant improvement in my reading, writing, and speaking abilities.
I learned how to read and write about 400 characters and develop my oral proficiency.
Over 400 Chinese characters, lots of grammar, and practice speaking and listening.

Learning how to write and read characters from scratch and also becoming more aware about tones when you speak. More confidence in speaking by speaking in class everyday. Learning a lot of new words and/or refreshing vocabulary that you've only heard about before.
Good intro to basic Chinese. Learned many new characters

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course load felt really heavy both in and out of class, but the professor taught the material well.
The professor is amazing, and the curriculum is designed well. No weaknesses!
The immersion in the language was really useful and made me more interested on studying on my own. There are a lot of assignments though.
Strengths: The course set reasonably high expectations for students, the teacher was very kind and encouraging, course material was interesting

I really like the 4+1 model where the last day of the week is asynchronous. I think it really gave the students a chance to integrate all that weve learned the previous days. The workload was a bit much especially when we had projects because the other assignments continued as usual though.
Daily meetings were crucial to retaining the lessons. Professor was great and small class size helped.
Strengths: constant refreshing of vocab and lots of speaking and writing practice.
Strength was speaking. Weakness was memorizing characters

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course but would advise the student to consider their course load beforehand.
Absolutely! This course taught me far more Chinese than several years of Saturday school. The professor is wonderful, and the class is meaningful.
I definitely recommend this to other students with an interest in Chinese.
I would strongly recommend this course to another student because it is an overall fun and engaging course with a strong support system.
Yes, it is a fantastic introductory Chinese course. For the heritage track, it really builds on the knowledge you already have.
For heritage speakers, definitely!!

Yes, if you grew up only listening to Chinese but barely speaking, this is a great course. You'll have to get use to always correcting your tones but it really does kick start your Chinese abilities. Also, we start at the true basics for writing, and I am a lot more confident in my reading and writing abilities.
Yes if you want to learn chinese
